description: From French fatigue, from fatiguer, from Latin fatīgāre (“to weary, tire, vex, harass”).

entries.meaning: A weariness caused by exertion; exhaustion.
(often in the plural) A menial task or tasks, especially in the military.
(engineering) Weakening and eventual failure of material, typically by cracking leading to complete separation, caused by repeated application of mechanical stress to the material.
examples: Mechanical failures due to fatigue have been the subject of engineering efforts for more than 150 years.

verbs.description: fatigue (third-person singular simple present fatigues, present participle fatiguing, simple past and past participle fatigued)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tire or make weary by physical or mental exertion.
(transitive, cooking) To wilt a salad by dressing or tossing it.
examples: The handsome, silver-haired proprietor was absorbed in fatiguing a salad for a family party.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To lose so much strength or energy that one becomes tired, weary, feeble or exhausted.
(intransitive, engineering, of a material specimen) To undergo the process of fatigue; to fail as a result of fatigue.
(transitive, engineering) To cause to undergo the process of fatigue.
examples: The repeated pressurization cycles fatigued the airplane's metal skin until it eventually broke up in flight.
